text: Can from Js. Pours a clear gold with a finger of head. Light grassy hops on the nose with some grainy notes. Clean and crisp on the finish with some floral peppery notes. Dry and crushable pils, but could be hoppy on the finish. Still solid.
Clear light yellow color, medium frothy white head with nice lacing. Slight lemon grass aroma. Medium body with a light wheat flavor and a mild bitter finish.

Poured from a can. Clear light yellow color, medium frothy white head with nice lacing. Slight lemon grass aroma. Medium body with a light wheat flavor and a mild bitter finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Light pour, thin white head. Sweet aroma, some light fruit. Flavor is light, also fruity. Lemongrass, citrus. Somewhat dry finish. OK.

Canned on May 6, 2016. Misty golden. Creamy white halo of foam. Very bright, focused, and uplifting "airy" aroma of lemon verbena, honeysuckle, pepper, cracker dough and uncured hay. Firm prickles of dense carbonation. Strikingly vibrant and flavorsome hops adorn the soft pils malt with a supple wave of oils on initial sip. Malt exhibits the well-mashed depth of baguette, yet retains just as much grassy levity which recalls uncured hay. Tremendously floral hop character boasts a softness akin to rose petals splashed lightly with nectar. Boundless lemony notes are harmoniously nestled against the herbal zippiness as they reinforce the multilayered hoppiness with considerable sophistication. A crackery snap to the malt ever so gently generates a tinge of dryness, supplying structure to the remarkably soft body while enlivening the underlying tickle of fennel seed herbality. Malt is amazingly lean, with a smidgeon of starchiness to enrich the body with sufficiency of texture. Integrated and squeaky-clean finish features grassy hay preceding oily, hard lemon-candylike hop flavors which linger in perpetuity. What we have here is an unabashedly hoppy and stylish pils thats German to the core (obviously the recipe has changed or the RB description is inaccurate, because this shares absolutely no parallels with Czech pils). It is very reminiscent of Pivo Pils from Firestone Walker, with that ultra vibrant and zingy Saphir note. But whereas that one can be brash and "green", this one is softer and more elegant without exchanging that for any hoppy dynamism. Discerning from the bright hop burps, this has been dry-hopped extensively, which is my only quibble since a well-made pils doesnt benefit from dry-hopping. So, who knows if the hops in this would seem raw and green in a really fresh can. Either way, Im truly impressed that this is still so vital after four months from packaging. A Hallertau bomb!
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text:
Draft at hotel. Pours golden with white head. Leaves trace lacing in the glass. Slight grass notes on the nose and tongue. Finished clean. Solid but not spectacular. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nice floral aroma, pours a slightly hazy straw with a thin white head. Clean bread malt flavor, with a very light body and a touch of sweetness. Crisp finish with floral and spicy hop notes. A very solid pilsner.

draft glass that poured a yellow color with white head. for me a pils is suppose to be sharp and crisp with a definite hop aroma and flavor. this was a litte mushy. the biggest put off was the floral hop flavor. was a little over the top in floral and there was no crispness to this one it kind of just slid off the tongue. really not a fan of this pils.
Draft - pours yellow white head - nose/taste of bread, moldy lemon - dry - med body
Draft - Lots of grains with a light sweetness, clear gold with a nice white frothy head. Dirty grainy notes with a almos astringent bitterness and very dry.
six pack in the hotel room of Cincinnati, Ohio. Right out of the can like a total degenerate. Mild bitterness, grass, pale malt base. Medium body and a crisp finish. decent.

Glad to see this on draft so I tickets this style. Draft to pint at Butterbees pours clear light straw yellow with thin white head. Nose crystal malt, fairly crisp, and light grain. Taste cleaner crisp up front, crystal malt, light apple, then moderate grainy malt mid palate. Nice flavors for a pilsner
4 oz pour on draft at ChurchKey. Clear pale yellow with off-white head. Aromas of citrus, wheat, herbs. Tastes of citrus, wheat, crisp notes. Light body with a dry finish.
At SAVOR. Poured a pale straw color with a small hazy body and a fixxy head. Aroma was some mild herbal notes, touch of very mild lemon, and a little grassy note to it. Lightly crisp.
Light saaz and decent barley presence. Golden pour with good head and lacing. Light crisp finish. Tap at Churchkey.
Draft at Churchkey. Clear bright yellow color. White pepper aroma. Taste is peppery hay. Crisp finish. Nice.

Can. Pours a pale straw color with a massive white fluffy head that dissipates to a filmy lace. Good cling. Substantial aroma of fresh Czech hops. Flavors are cut grass, a touch of honey, citrus, toasted grain, and baked bread. Finishes with a resiny hop bite. Clean mouthfeel. Very delicious.

Sampled at GABF 2015. In the tasting glass was a very clear light gold with a white cap of foam. nose of citrus, grassy hops, and light fruit. Light in body but slick in the mouth. Flavor is a good balance of citrus, floral, and fruity hops. The finish just the perfect bitter you look for in this style. Excellent pils.

Sample during the "Beer And Food Pairing" hosted by rogueone on 02/21/2016, paired with candied bacon. The beer is a clear golden color with a medium thin white head that evaporates steadily to a wispy film. Spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma of grassy hops, fruit and malt. Light-bodied with flavors of floral hops, fruit and biscuit malt. The finish is mildly bitter with a grassy hops aftertaste. Decent overall.

Twelve ounce can from Delhi Liquor Store, tasted on May 23, 2015. Floral/fruity bittersweet nose, moderate bittersweet flavor with not as much pilsner sharpness as other examples of the style. Sessionable and also a good intro beer for craft novices
Sampled at gabf. Clear light holden. A nice Pils nose. This us to style. Nicely done. Earthy spicy hops. Soft malts. If an Ametican brewer can do a Pils they can brew beer.
Can. Light honey lemon, barley malt and straw aroma. Pale yellow with giant white head. Sweet light citrus barley malt and moderately bitter herbal grass flavor. Decent body.

Can:
Clear, pale gold with a small white head.
Honey, grains, floral scent.
Taste is a steady floral bitter, grains, pisner malt.
Solid.

12 ounce can poured into a pilsener glass. The beer is clear gold with a fluffy white head of foam. Good Retention. The aroma has soft honey and some crisp, grassy, green tea-like notes. The taste is softly sweet, but also has a slightly dry bitterness on the backend, after the swallow. Lighter in body and medium to high carbonation.

Clear pale yellow. Almost no head. Light floral hop aroma. Very light and crisp. A bit bready

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Can - nose is straight up grass. Sip adds a floral hop element. Mildly bitter. Meh and mildly refreshing. Has that eastern european grain feel.

Oh my, this is a fine beer indeed! It is straw yellow w/ a foamy head. It has a brilliant floral hop character, bright and subtle. Its got a bready malt character and a kiss of sweetness helps bring out some lemon zest citrus and seems to highlight the firm but gentle bitterness in the finish. This is a medium bodied beer w/ softly vigorous carbonation. I am not sure this is spot on the the Czech style but its exactly what I want out of a Pilsner, magnificently drinkable w/ tons of noble hop character.

12 oz can. Pale straw, small head that totally disappears; not much to look at. Bread, grass, pear, floral hops, banana, maybe honey; dry finish with a solid dose of bitterness. Medium-thin palate; some slickness to the carbonation. Pretty good pils.
Can. Pours clear gold with a white head. Pale grainy malts, light flowery notes, low sweetness, and mild bitterness. Clean and very drinkable. Quite good.
12 ounce can. Very light and clean yellow pour. Crisp. Bready. Aroma of light hops and grass. Clean.

Got this from some of the bros from the brewery. 12 oz can with a date code 060415, so pretty damn fresh. Pours a brilliantly clear golden with no head. Bready, grainy aroma with some hops and a hint of green apple. Light and crisp on the tongue. Get more acetaldehyde as it warms up, so I drank it quickly. Light and refreshing. Pretty solid.

12oz can from Giant Eagle in Upper Arlington: murky yellow gold pour with a big bright white head. aroma of bready, floral, perfume. tastes are malt, grass, lager yeast, moderate bready sweet. palate is oily light to medium. solid overall.
A nice pilsner with a good nose. Pours a clear golden and has a good taste. Head was thick.

Nice floral pilsner nose thin fading head very clear. Taste is nice sweet good floral with excellent carb one of best pils I've had. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

バイツェンの  
あまりないか&

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2015 Draft: and Can: This beer is light in most everything... color aromas and taste, but dont take that as a bad thing.  Its an exercise in subtlety, and in that its very well executed.  This is full of light earthy grass and straw notes, with some really nice citrus lingering behind it all.  Very tasty.

Aroma: More tropical fruity in the nose than youd except with a Pilsner, but with a strong grassy hop presence as well; malts are crackery as youd expect. Appearance: Royal gold pour with a creamy white head that settles into a white skin. Flavor: More grassy than tropical (as far as hop go); a bit more lemon character toward the finish with a sustained, but light, cracker presence. Palate: Light body, sticky texture, soft carbonation, lingering finish. Overall: My first Rhinegeist beer, and a wonderful one at that. Very nice pils.

Decent Czech pils. Light golden color, thin head, malty taste. Finishes smooth and light enough for a good summer beer and one to new craft beer drinkers. If youre looking for another session from Rhinegeist with a bit more pop, get the hoppy Zen.

Pint on tap at Dutchs. Keg filled 6/18/14. Half hazy golden orange color. Leaves good thicker bits of lace initially, head and lace soon fades though. Medium body. Super smooth, kind of crisp, lighter carbonation. Awesome bready doughy malt, seeing some of the mild honey. Light peppery and floral hop. Fruitier aromas than your typical pilsener. Moderate sweet taste, light bitter. Very satisfying well-done pilsener. Good unique flavor profile to it, a satisfying Rhinegeist twist. I could drink this type of thing all day long.

Draft at the brewery. Pours a cloudy gold, on the paler side of the scale, with a white head that leaves some streaks of lace in the glass. Loads of sweet bready malts, with banana, sugar, grass, and honey. Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a malty mouthfeel. A bit too big and overly sweet. Doesnt drink like a pils.

Draft. Gold pour, white head. Good retention/some lace. Aroma of bread, grassy hop, lager yeast. Taste is moderately bitter, grassy, some sweetness. Palate is drier, average carbonation, slick, slight bitter finish.

Draft. Poured a clear pale color with a moderate frothy white head that lasted and had good lacing. Medium floral hop and earthy sweet malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. This beer exceeded my expectations.

Draft to pint at Rhinegeist. Looks good; a slightly hazy golden orange with foamy white head. Smells of mild hops, pilsner malt, and lager yeast. Tastes like it smells with a solid mouthfeel. A bit of biscuit too. Could be snappier, but enjoyable nonetheless.
